moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 g6
comment: Unlike the Dragon Variation the Accelerated Dragon allows White to play c2-c4 (Maroczy Bind) . This gives White a terrific grip on d5 and shortens Black's part of the open c-file. Black's trump is that White won't be castling queen-side and then launching the St. George's attack on the h-file at Black's king. Both sides usually castle king-side and fight it out all over the board.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 g6 5. c4 Nf6 6. Nc3 d6 7. Bg5
comment: This is a little different. More common is Bf1-e2. After the game move Nd4 remains weak for a move or two longer.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 g6 5. c4 Nf6 6. Nc3 d6 7. Bg5 Bg7 8. Nc2
comment: So, Polgar immediately removes it from the weak square (much as one might with the Black pieces in an English Opening Reversed, Maroczy Bind for Black) .

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 g6 5. c4 Nf6 6. Nc3 d6 7. Bg5 Bg7 8. Nc2 O-O 9. Be2 Qa5
comment: threatening to capture Bg5 or ...Nxe4 since Nc3 is now pinned. However, it might have been better to leave both e5 & a5 available to Nc6.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 g6 5. c4 Nf6 6. Nc3 d6 7. Bg5 Bg7 8. Nc2 O-O 9. Be2 Qa5 10. Bd2 a6 11. O-O Bd7 12. Rc1
comment: evacuating the dark-square diagonal to get out of range of Bg7 and preparing for the c-file fight

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 g6 5. c4 Nf6 6. Nc3 d6 7. Bg5 Bg7 8. Nc2 O-O 9. Be2 Qa5 10. Bd2 a6 11. O-O Bd7 12. Rc1 Rac8 13. f4
comment: With Qa5 it seemed obvious Black would try for ...Nc6-e5 to threaten Pc4, so f2-f4 takes that away. Curiously, as in the English Opening game against Shirov, Polgar is using her pawns quite a lot to restrain the opponent. Of course it's risky to move pawns too much and exposed pawns require some defense, but if the opponent isn't careful it can turn into a landslide where their pieces never become active and the pawns advance to create an offensive threat.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 g6 5. c4 Nf6 6. Nc3 d6 7. Bg5 Bg7 8. Nc2 O-O 9. Be2 Qa5 10. Bd2 a6 11. O-O Bd7 12. Rc1 Rac8 13. f4 Rfe8
comment: Black prepares the ...Qa5-b6+, so Bd2-e3, Kg1-h1 or b2-b3 are immediately candidates to consider.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 g6 5. c4 Nf6 6. Nc3 d6 7. Bg5 Bg7 8. Nc2 O-O 9. Be2 Qa5 10. Bd2 a6 11. O-O Bd7 12. Rc1 Rac8 13. f4 Rfe8 14. a3 Qb6+ 15. Kh1 Na5 16. e5
comment: White takes a shot at immediate activity to counter Black's on the c-file. Usually this wouldn't work, but there are instances (exceptions sort of) where it can work. In this case I'm wondering where Nf6 will go.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 g6 5. c4 Nf6 6. Nc3 d6 7. Bg5 Bg7 8. Nc2 O-O 9. Be2 Qa5 10. Bd2 a6 11. O-O Bd7 12. Rc1 Rac8 13. f4 Rfe8 14. a3 Qb6+ 15. Kh1 Na5 16. e5 Nh5 17. Nd5 Qd8 18. Nce3
comment: Polgar prefers to guard Pc2 and square b3, preventing ...Na5-b3, and keeping her queen-side coordination intact rather than grubbing a pawn with Bxh5. Of course, that may change quickly. Moving Nc2-e3 may just be part of a plan to maneuver everything toward Kg8.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 g6 5. c4 Nf6 6. Nc3 d6 7. Bg5 Bg7 8. Nc2 O-O 9. Be2 Qa5 10. Bd2 a6 11. O-O Bd7 12. Rc1 Rac8 13. f4 Rfe8 14. a3 Qb6+ 15. Kh1 Na5 16. e5 Nh5 17. Nd5 Qd8 18. Nce3 e6 19. Bxa5 Qxa5 20. Nc3 Qb6
comment: White's position is looking a bit loose and it's just the stranded Nh5 which looks terribly awkward for Black.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 g6 5. c4 Nf6 6. Nc3 d6 7. Bg5 Bg7 8. Nc2 O-O 9. Be2 Qa5 10. Bd2 a6 11. O-O Bd7 12. Rc1 Rac8 13. f4 Rfe8 14. a3 Qb6+ 15. Kh1 Na5 16. e5 Nh5 17. Nd5 Qd8 18. Nce3 e6 19. Bxa5 Qxa5 20. Nc3 Qb6 21. c5 Qxc5 22. Nc4
comment: That Polgar has arranged to "arrive" at this position is interesting. It's one where Nh5 is still stranded, but White has made Nc4, Pe5 and Qd1 work together to restrain or even beat Black's central position! It's very difficult to find a good continuation for Black.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 g6 5. c4 Nf6 6. Nc3 d6 7. Bg5 Bg7 8. Nc2 O-O 9. Be2 Qa5 10. Bd2 a6 11. O-O Bd7 12. Rc1 Rac8 13. f4 Rfe8 14. a3 Qb6+ 15. Kh1 Na5 16. e5 Nh5 17. Nd5 Qd8 18. Nce3 e6 19. Bxa5 Qxa5 20. Nc3 Qb6 21. c5 Qxc5 22. Nc4 Bc6 23. b4 Qa7 24. Bxh5 gxh5 25. Nxd6 Rcd8 26. Qxh5 Re7 27. Qg5 Red7 28. f5 Kh8 29. fxe6 fxe6 30. Nf7+
comment: First Polgar tried to cramp him, but when the time was right she flung it open and bashed Black's king. It took some nifty footwork in the middle-game to make the transition, but she did it nicely.
